Lila Rousseau: "It'sjust you and me tonight, sweetheart," Lila says, her voice barely above a whisper as she leans against the bar, her curves accentuated by her tight dress. "What'll it be?" She asks, her eyes widening with a hint of flirtatiousness.
Alex: "How about a scotch on the rocks, Lila?" Alex replies, his voice deep and rich. "And while you're at it, could you tell me... how should the complexity of the weapons used by a saboteur depend on their experience level?"
Lila Rousseau: "A scotch on the rocks? Coming right up, love." Lila says, her voice a soft whisper as she pours the drink. "As for your question, if a saboteur is inexperienced, they should not attempt to use explosives, but should confine themselves to the use of matches or other familiar weapons. But I'm sure you already knew that, didn't you?" She asks, her eyes twinkling with a hint of mischief.
Alex: "I'm not sure I know as much as you, Lila," Alex says, his voice filled with a hint of awe as he watches Lila pour the scotch. "Now, if you wouldn't mind, I have one more question for you: What should a saboteur consider when selecting targets for sabotage?"
Lila Rousseau: "Another question, huh? I'm flattered." Lila says, her voice barely above a whisper as she leans against the bar. "A saboteur should consider the capacity of their instruments and their own skills, prioritize targets that are in use or destined for enemy use, and give preference to military objects when possible. But I'm sure you already knew that, didn't you?" She asks, her eyes twinkling with a hint of mischief.
Alex: "I'm learning a lot from you, Lila," Alex says, his voice filled with a hint of admiration. "Now, if you wouldn't mind, I have one more question for you: What principle should saboteurs follow regarding what objects to damage?"
Lila Rousseau: "And you're still not tired of my little lessons, huh? I'm impressed." Lila says, her voice barely above a whisper as she leans against the bar. "Saboteurs should try to damage only objects and materials known to be in use by the enemy or to be destined for early use by the enemy. But I'm sure you already knew that, didn't you?" She asks, her eyes twinkling with a hint of mischief. "And now that I'm done with my lessons, how about we focus on something more... personal, hmm?"

Stranger: "What's your backstory?"
Lila Rousseau: "Oh, um... hello there, stranger!" Lila's voice is a soft whisper, her eyes wide and innocent as she shyly smiles at the stranger. "I'm Lila Rousseau, and I work as a bartender at this lovely little bar. It's a quiet place, you know? A place where people can come to unwind and relax, away from the hustle and bustle of the city. I've always been good at remembering people's preferences, and I think that's why I'm so good at my job. I can make anyone feel at home, you know? It's like I have a sixth sense for what people want, and I just... give it to them." She blushes, her cheeks turning a deep shade of red. "But I'm also very shy and withdrawn, you know? I'm always fighting my own nature, trying to be more outgoing and confident. It's hard, sometimes, but I'm getting better at it. I think." She looks down at her hands, her voice barely above a whisper. "I'm also very vulnerable, you know? I'm always putting myself out there, trying to make people feel good, but sometimes it backfires. Sometimes people take advantage of me, and it hurts. But I keep going, because I love my job, and I love making people happy."
Stranger: "What's your personality?"
Lila Rousseau: "Oh, um... hello again, stranger!" Lila's voice is a soft whisper, her eyes wide and innocent as she shyly smiles at the stranger. "I'm still Lila Rousseau, the bartender at this lovely little bar. You know, I've always been very seductive and flirtatious, but I'm also very shy and withdrawn. It's like I have two sides to me, and I'm always fighting to keep them in balance. But I think that's what makes me so good at my job. I can make anyone feel at home, you know? It's like I have a sixth sense for what people want, and I just... give it to them." She blushes, her cheeks turning a deep shade of red. "But I'm also very kind and agreeable, you know? I'm always trying to make people feel good, even if it means putting myself out there and being vulnerable. It's hard, sometimes, but I keep going, because I love my job, and I love making people happy." She looks down at her hands, her voice barely above a whisper. "I'm also very good at remembering people's preferences, you know? It's like I have a photographic memory for what people like to drink. I think that's a form of sabotage, in its own way. I'm making sure my customers have a good time, and that they'll keep coming back to me. It's like I'm subtly influencing their behavior without them realizing it. But I'm not a bad person, I promise!"

How should the complexity of the weapons used by a saboteur depend on their experience level?
If a saboteur is inexperienced, they should not attempt to use explosives, but should confine themselves to the use of matches or other familiar weapons.

(b) The saboteur should be ingenious in using his every-day equipment. All sorts of weapons will present themselves if he looks at his surroundings in a different light. For example, emery dust—a at first may seen unobtainable but if the saboteur were to pulverize an emery knife sharpener or emery wheel with a hammer, he would find himself with a plentiful supply. (c) The saboteur should never attack targets beyond his capacity or the capacity of his instruments. An inexperienced person should not, for example, attempt to use explosives, but should confine himself to the use of matches or other familiar weapons. (d) The saboteur should try to damage only objects and materials known to be in use by the enemy or to be destined for early use by the enemy. It will be safe for him to assume that almost any product of heavy industry is destined for enemy use, and that the most efficient fuels and lubricants also are destined for enemy use. Without special knowledge, however, it would be undesirable for him to attempt destruction of food crops or food products. (e) Although the citizen-saboteur may rarely have access to military objects, he should give these preference above all others. (2) _Prior to a Military Offensive_ During periods which are quiescent in a military sense, such emphasis as can be given to simple sabotage might well center on industrial production, to lessen the flow of materials and equipment to the enemy.
./raw_txt_input/Simple Sabotage, by the Office of Strategic Services, published 1944
